speaker: Neil
text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English – the programme where we bring you an interesting topic and six items of vocabulary. I'm Neil.

speaker: Catherine
text: And I'm Catherine. Today we're taking a look into the lives of the super rich – and we're going to look at one of their favourite pastimes.

speaker: assets
text: The super rich are people with over $30 million US dollars of assets.

speaker: Assets
text: Assets are things we can own and sell – like property, boats and private planes.

speaker: Neil
text: Expensive toys. First things first, let's do our question, Catherine. In which country is the percentage of super rich expected to grow fastest over the next 10 years?

speaker: Neil
text: a)    China

speaker: Neil
text: b)    Brazil

speaker: Neil
text: c)    Vietnam?

speaker: Catherine
text: I'm going to go for Vietnam. I think, that's an up and coming country and I think there is going to be a lot of growth in wealth in the future.

speaker: Neil
text: Ok, well we'll find out if you are right or wrong later. The number of super rich are expected to increase by 43% over the next decade.

speaker: Catherine
text: Now, this doesn't mean income is rising at the same speed for everyone. You might remember a report last year which said the world's richest 62 individuals owned as much as the poorest 50% of people in the whole world.

speaker: Neil
text: So, my question is – what on earth do people with so much money spend it on?

speaker: Catherine
text: One academic in the UK has been researching just that. And her answer is …, Neil?

speaker: status symbol
text: Yachts! A yacht – a luxury boat used for pleasure. The ultimate status symbol – that is, an item which allows you to show off your wealth and position in society.

speaker: Catherine
text: Let's listen to Emma Spence from Cardiff University in the UK. What's so unusual about yachts?

speaker: assetsmakebusiness senseblack hole
text: If you have an exclusive wine collection or art collection or even the purchase of a business jet – these are investable assets – something that you can retain value on or accrue value on. A business jet, a private jet, can cut costs – and make businesses more convenient by running faster, more comfortably than commercial airlines. So these purchases, they make good, sound business sense. Whereas a superyacht is essentially a black hole.

speaker: assetsmade business sense
text: Before we get to the yacht, Emma talked about certain assets like planes and wine that made business sense.

speaker: makes business sense
text: Now, to make sense – is a phrase you'll be familiar with. So, if we say something makes business sense, it means 'it's good for business'. But yachts are different.

speaker: black hole
text: Yachts, and especially what she calls superyachts, actually lose money. So much so, she calls a superyacht a black hole of wealth.

speaker: black hole
text: A black hole, in scientific terms, is a place where gravity is so strong that nothing can escape – not even light. So, in business terms, a black hole eats all your money!

speaker: Neil
text: It's also used conversationally to mean 'a place where things go missing'.

speaker: Catherine
text: These superyachts are big. The world's longest is 180m in length. And they require a professional crew. Which is how Emma began her study – she used to work on the yachts.

speaker: Neil
text: She's now spent six years studying the world of superyachts and the super rich.

speaker: Catherine
text: So, what else did she learn?

speaker: the pecking order
text: She says that in the world of the super rich – the size of your yacht shows your place in the pecking order.

speaker: pecking order
text: The pecking order means 'the social system from most powerful to least powerful'.

speaker: pecking order
text: If you're higher up in the yachting pecking order, you get the best place in the harbour. Which is very important to yacht owners, apparently.

speaker: conspicuous consumptionconspicuous consumption
text: Apparently, so. It's all about seeing and being seen. You could actually say that yachts are the ultimate form of conspicuous consumption. Now that's another great term – conspicuous means 'visible or noticeable' and consumption means 'spending'. So, the phrase conspicuous consumption refers to the kind of buying you do so that other people notice your money.

speaker: Neil
text: Before we sail off into the sunset Catherine, how about we answer today's question.

speaker: Catherine
text: I said that Vietnam is the country in which the percentage of super rich is expected to grow fastest over the next 10 years.

speaker: Neil
text: Well, I'm very pleased to say that you were right. It was in fact Vietnam – according to the same report by Knight Frank – the population of ultra wealthy is expected to grow by a staggering 170% in the next decade.

speaker: Catherine
text: Now, how about we have another look at the wealth of vocabulary in this programme?

speaker: assets
text: Very good. We started with assets – here it means 'things we can buy or sell'. What are your assets?

speaker: status symbol
text: Oh, you know, my diamond rings, my bike, my laptop. I'm not like you though Neil, I don't live in an expensive mansion – that would be a real status symbol!

speaker: status symbol
text: If only that were true, but it's a good example. A status symbol is a possession that shows off our wealth and our place in society.

speaker: make business sense
text: Yes, and we had the phrase to make business sense – in other words to be good for business. We could also say that a particular policy makes economic sense.

speaker: black hole
text: Or I could say investing wisely makes financial sense. Not like yachts which are expensive to buy and run. In fact, they're a black hole for our money.

speaker: pecking order
text: Now, did you know our next phrase, pecking order, actually comes from chicken behaviour?

speaker: conspicuous consumptionconspicuous consumption
text: And finally, the phrase conspicuous consumption. For example, you could say that dining at the finest restaurants wearing expensive clothes is conspicuous consumption.

speaker: status symbolconspicuous consumption
text: And to clear up two similar phrases: a status symbol refers to the object itself, like a luxury car; whereas conspicuous consumption refers to the act of spending money on things like expensive cars but you're spending money so that other people notice.
